clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Changing Sedentary Behavior in Youth
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Changing Sedentary Behavior in Youth

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York at Buffalo

clinical_study.source: State University of New York at Buffalo

brief_summary.textblock: The primary aim is to examine relative reinforcing value (RRV) of physical activity to sedentary behaviors as a predictor of substitution of physical activity for sedentary behaviors when sedentary behaviors are reduced. The investigators predict that there will be a significant positive relationship between RRV and substitution of physical activity for sedentary behavior when sedentary behavior is reduced. The investigators also predict that there will be a significant positive relationship between reduction in sedentary behaviors and energy intake and dietary fat.

arm_group.description: All participants reduce their TV/video/game time using a TV allowance device to reduce 0, 25 and 50% of their baseline times. Male and female youth are divided into low and high activity reward groups on the basis of a median split in how hard they will work for sedentary behaviors in comparison to physically active behaviors.

intervention.description: A TV allowance helps turn off the television when the time limits have been met.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- above the 85th BMI percentile
- reside in one primary household
- engage in at least 18 hours of sedentary behavior a week
